| Hazy Center in Chantilly, Virginia
}} 'Space ShuttleDiscovery' (Orbiter Vehicle Designation: 'OV-103') is one of
the retired orbiters of the Space Shuttle program of NASA, the space agency of
the United States, and was operational from its maiden
flight, STS-41-D on August 30, 1984, until its final landing during STS-133 on
March 9, 2011. Discovery has flown more than any other spacecraft having
completed 39 successful missions in over 27 years of service. [http://www.space.com/15327-space-shuttle-discovery-10-cool-
facts.html?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+spacehead-
lines+%28SPACE.com+Headline+Feed%29 facts about Discovery]

In 1984, Discovery became the third operational orbiter following [[Space
Shuttle Columbia|Columbia]] and [[Space Shuttle
Challenger|Challenger]], and made its final touchdown at Kennedy
Space Center on March 9, 2011 at 10:57:17 CST, having spent a
cumulative total of almost a full year in space. Discovery has performed both
research and International Space Station (ISS) assembly missions. Discovery also
flew the Hubble Space Telescope into orbit. Discovery was the first operational
shuttle to be retired, followed by [[Space Shuttle Endeavour|Endeavour]] and
then [[Space Shuttle Atlantis|Atlantis]].
categories: Individual spacecraft in the collection of the Smithsonian Institution
